1-Conductors
Materials that allow electricity to pass through them easily are called electrical conductors.
Examples of these materials:
1. Metals, such as iron, steel, copper, and aluminum. 2. Water also conducts electricity, which is why electrical objects should not be used near water.
Examples of metal used in conductors:
Electrical objects use metal parts to conduct electricity, such as:
1. The copper wires inside electrical leads. 2. The metal pins in plugs. 3. The metal wire ﬁlaments in light bulbs.
In a simple electrical circuit, copper wire is used to carry electricity from the energy source (such as a battery) to an electrical component (such as a lamp, motor, or bell).
01
Level 01 - Electricity - Lesson 03

2-insulators
Materials that do not allow electricity to pass through them are called electrical insulators.
Examples of these materials:
1. Plastic. 2. Rubber. 3. Wood. 4. Glass. 5. Air is also an insulator.
• Most electrical objects are made using insulators to keep them safe. Plugs, for example, have plastic cases. Electrical wires are wrapped in plastic, which is ﬂexible as well as insulating.
• The copper wires used in simple electrical circuits are coated in plastic. This prevents electricity from ﬂowing out of the circuit

A battery is a device that converts chemical energy contained within its active materials directly into electric using an electrochemical oxidation-reduction (redox) reaction.
This type of reaction involves the transfer of electrons from one material to another via an electric circuit.
A chemical reaction between the metals and the electrolyte frees more electrons in one metal than it does in the other.
The metal that frees more electrons develops a positive charge, and the other metal develops a negative charge.

INTRODUCTION TO MECHANICS
In these lessons you will learn some basic concepts of mechanical engineering.
Level 01 - Mechatronics - Lesson 02

What Is Force?
Have you ever been in the middle of enjoying a scrumptious piece of food, and just as it enters your mouth...splat, it slips out of your hands and falls on the ﬂoor? If so, then you've experienced force.
Force happens all around us, all of the time. Force is a push or a pull of an object that causes the object to speed up, slow down, or stay in one place. In other words, a force is what causes an object to move. Friction and gravity are two types of forces that inﬂuence how an object moves. Let's learn more about them.
Watch a video
https://www.youtube. com/watch?v=7_9fMF Gfy9w Scan Here!
Push and Pull Forces A push is the force that moves an object away from something, like when you push a plate of Brussels sprouts away in disgust. We use the force of push when we kick a soccer ball, press the gas peddle of a car, push our chair in, and press the buttons on a phone.
A push and a pull are opposite forces, meaning they move objects in different directions. Therefore, a pull is the force of bringing an object closer. We use the force Ball changes direction of a pull when we move our bowl of ice cream closer to us, open a door, or climb up a rope.
Level 01 - Mechatronics - Lesson 02

The Force of Friction
Friction is the force that acts to slow an object down. Imagine trying to ride your bike through sand. Just thinking about this can make your legs burn from all the hard work. That is because the sand is a type of friction. In other words, it's a force working against your legs as they push against the peddles.
Watch a video
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PNDRIicw4E0 Scan Here!
Level 01 - Mechatronics - Lesson 02

The Force of Gravity
Gravity is the pulling of an object towards Earth's center. When a ball is thrown up in the air, it slows down and falls back to the ground. That is because gravity pulls the ball back towards the earth.
Watch a video
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ed7rg7MuuEQ Scan Here!
Everything on Earth is inﬂuenced by the force of gravity.

Simple machines
(pulley – inclined plane – wheel - lever – screw)
We use simple machines every day – when we open a door, turn on a tap, open a tin, or ride a bike. Simple machines make it easy for us to do work.
Pulley
Pulleys are made by looping a rope over one or more wheels. They are often used to lift heavy objects: pulling down on one end of the rope creates an upward pull at the other end.
Watch a video
https://www.youtube.c om/watch?v=hjFMZek hoXU&list=PL786ED3C B23AE24E8&index=4 Scan Here!
Inclined plane
An inclined plane is one of the six types of simple machines. It's exactly what it sounds like - it is a plane (a ﬂat surface) that is inclined, or slanted, at an acute angle. Inclined planes connect a lower level to a higher level; they make work easier.
Inclined planes have been around for thousands of years. They were even used to make the building of the ancient pyramids easier! Today, inclined planes continue to be a big part of our world.
Watch a video
https://www.youtube.c om/watch?v=ByLXZCP 4ixc&t=122s Scan Here!

Lever
A lever is most commonly deﬁned as a rod or arm that tilts around a pivot, also called a fulcrum, to produce useful motion. The load is moved by the effort (a push or pull) used to make the lever tilt about the pivot.
Levers are found in many machines, such as wheelbarrows, oars, rakes, nutcrackers, tweezers, screwdrivers, snow shovels, hammers, bottle openers, light switches, staplers, crowbars, scissors and see-saws.

The main Idea
3D modeling is the process of creating a digital 3D representation of an object. This can be done using a variety of software programs, such as TinkerCAD, SolidWorks, and Fusion.
Once a 3D model is created, it can be used for a variety of purposes, such as:
Computer-aided design (CAD): 3D models can be used to create CAD models, which are used in engineering and manufacturing to design and prototype new products.
3D printing: 3D printing is the process of creating a physical object from a digital 3D model.
Virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR): 3D models can be used to create immersive VR and AR experiences. This can be used for a variety of applications, such as gaming, training, and education.
Level 01 - Design [Tinker CAD] - Lesson 01

3D modeling is a challenging process, but it is also a very rewarding one. With the right tools and skills, you can create anything you can imagine.
Let’s start with Computer-aided
design (CAD)
First
You have a set of 2D and 3D shapes can you recognize the difference.
The main difference between 2D and 3D is the number of dimensions they have. 2D objects have two dimensions, length and width, while 3D objects have three dimensions, length, width, and height. This means that 2D objects can only be represented on a ﬂat surface, while 3D objects can be represented in a three-dimensional space.
Second
You can design any 3D shapes using Tinker CAD software.
Autodesk’s Tinkercad app is probably the easiest, most accessible and most fun 3D modeling application for creating your ﬁrst 3D print. No previous 3D modeling experience needed and best of all: this 3D design app is totally free.
